caption.p: Table detailing food-system-associated disease emergence events, including context, transmission modes, and risk factors identified in literature review

tr.th: Confirmed or probable transmission routes (Jones et al. 2008 categories)
Contact event type/food system risk behavior

tr.td: Increasing niche overlap, stressed food security, greater wildlife access
Shifting species ranges, stressed food security
Human to human or international spread
Leroy et al. ( 2009); Pigott et al. ( 2014)
Horseshoe bats (Rhinolophus spp. infection also found in masked palm civets, pigs)
Extensive trade of wild caught species, interspecies mixing inmarket setting
Human to human or international spread
Li et al. ( 2005a, b); Wang et al. ( 2006); Shi and Hu ( 2008)
Human to human or international spread
Hahn ( 2000a, b); Wolfe et al. ( 2005a, b)
Wild rodents (Mastomys natalensis, Natal multi-mammate mouse)
Endemic in Guinea, Liberia, Sierra Leone, and regions of Nigeria
Regional epidemics, with little human-to-human transmission
Elevated reservoir numbers (greater availability as food)
Elevated reservoir numbers around grain storage
Aquatic birds, poultry, swine. Infection found in other mammals.
Widespread. Azerbaijan, Cambodia, China, Djibouti, Egypt, Indonesia, Iraq, Lao People's Democratic Republic, Myanmar, Nigeria, Pakistan, Thailand, Turkey, Vietnam.
Shifting species ranges (poultry–wildlife contact), stressed food security (increased poultry numbers and densities)
Pigs (mostly asymptomatic amplifying host), wading birds (reservoir host), mosquito vector
Epidemics, but without human-to-human transmission (humans are dead-end hosts)
Land clearance and flooding for rice and pig production (increased vector population, domestic animal amplifier)
Shifting species ranges (mosquito), stressed food security (increased pig numbers and densities)
Campbell et al. ( 2011); Centers for Disease Control ( 2013)
Wildlife–domestic animal–human; farming activities (also consumption of contaminated date palm sap in Bangladesh)
Increasing niche overlap (bat hosts losing habitat)
Shifting species ranges (bat hosts), stressed food security (increased pig numbers and densities, mixed cropping)
Luby et al. ( 2006); Rahman et al. ( 2010); Pulliam et al. ( 2011)
Fruit bats (suspected reservoir host), pigs (amplifier host)
Increasing niche overlap (bat hosts losing habitat)
Shifting species ranges (bat contact with pigs)
Kirkland et al. ( 2001); Center for Food Security and Public Health ( 2007)
Rodents (Calomys musculinus, dry lands vesper mouse; Calomys laucha, small vesper mouse)
Elevated reservoir numbers around food storage
Maiztegui ( 1975); Public Health Agency of Canada ( 2010)
Elevated reservoir numbers around food storage
Johnson et al. ( 1997a, b); Young et al. ( 1998a, b)
Elevated reservoir numbers around food storage
Unknown, multiple (rodents, including Gambian rats, striped mice, dormice, rope and tree squirrels; primates)
Democratic Republic of Congo, Sudan, elsewhere in Congo Basin and western Africa. Cases also seen in Midwestern United States
Wildlife–human; handling, contact with infected animals and people or bodily fluids thereof
Extensive trade of wild caught species
Human to human or international spread
Wild rodents (Mastomys natalensis, Natal multimammate mouse)
Endemic in Guinea, Liberia, Sierra Leone, and regions of Nigeria
Regional epidemics, with little human-to-human transmission
Elevated reservoir numbers around food storage

table-wrap-foot.p: Color shadings relate to importance to the event, based on our judgment from our literature review. Darker factors are more proximate or directly related to the event
